examples.text: the fight against terrorism
We're playing against the league champions next week.
We were rowing against the current.
That's against the law.
Employees can't be forced to join a union against their will.
Are you for or against the death penalty?
She is against seeing *(= does not want to see)* him.
I'd advise you against doing that.

definitions.definition: not to the advantage or favour of somebody/something

examples.text: The evidence is against him.
Her age is against her.

definitions.definition: close to, touching or hitting somebody/something

examples.text: Put the piano there, against the wall.
The rain beat against the windows.

definitions.definition: in order to prevent something from happening or to reduce the damage caused by something

examples.text: an injection against rabies
They took precautions against fire.
Are we insured against theft?
He gritted his teeth against the pain.

definitions.definition: with something in the background, as a contrast

examples.text: His red clothes stood out clearly against the snow.
The love story unfolds against a background of civil war.

definitions.definition: used when you are comparing two things

examples.text: You must weigh the benefits against the cost.
Check your receipts against the statement.
What's the rate of exchange against the dollar?

definitions.definition: if you include money or costs against an amount that is owed, you use it to reduce the amount

examples.text: The accountant said I could offset all my travel costs against tax.

definitions.definition: if you borrow money against property that you own, you use the value of the property as a guarantee that you will repay the money

examples.text: They had borrowed a lot of money against the value of the house.
They got 27 per cent of the vote as against 32 per cent at the last election.

definitions.definition: you are unlikely to succeed because the conditions are not good for you

wordOrigin: Middle English: from again + -s (adverbial genitive) + -t probably by association with superlatives (as in amongst).
